It sounds like you're getting your coffee game back on track!

First, let's tackle the water filter replacement. Congratulations on finding the instruction manual! Replacing the water filter every 1-2 months is a great habit to maintain the taste and quality of your coffee. Make sure to follow the instructions in the manual to replace the filter correctly. It's usually a simple process that involves removing the old filter, rinsing the area, and inserting a new one.

Once you've replaced the filter, you can move on to exploring the built-in grinder on your coffee maker. The grinder is usually a convenient feature that allows you to freshly grind your coffee beans just before brewing. Here are some general tips to get you started:

1. Check the manual: Refer to the instruction manual to understand how to operate the grinder specifically on your coffee maker model.
2. Choose your grind setting: Adjust the grinder to the desired coarseness or fineness depending on your preferred brewing method.
3. Measure your beans: Add the recommended amount of coffee beans to the grinder. The manual might provide a guideline for the ideal amount.
4. Grind the beans: Place the beans in the grinder and close the lid. The grinder will do its magic, and you'll be left with freshly ground coffee.
5. Brew your coffee: Add the ground coffee to the filter, and brew your coffee as usual.

Remember to clean the grinder regularly to prevent any residual coffee oils from affecting the flavor of your brew.

Now that you've tackled the water filter and grinder, you're all set to experiment with new coffee recipes! What type of coffee are you planning to try out first?
